facts.text: Petition No. 115 of 1956 and Petition No. 132 of 1956 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 115 of 1956, and Petition No. 132 of 1956. Petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Petitions heard together on February 13, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India, Porus Mehta and R. H. Dhebar, for the respondents, 1957. February 13. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS J.-

facts.text: Baij Nath Prasad Tripathi was petitioner in Petition No. 115 of 1956 and was a Sub-inspector of Police in the then State of Bhopal.

anchor.surface_text: Baij Nath Prasad Tripathi, petitioner in Petition No. 115 of 1956, was a Sub-inspector of Police in the then State of Bhopal.

facts.text: Baij Nath Prasad Tripathi prosecuted in the Court of Shri B. K. Puranik, Special Judge, Bhopal.

anchor.surface_text: He was prosecuted in the Court of Shri B. K. Puranik, Special Judge, Bhopal, and companyvicted of offences under s. 161, Indian Penal Code, and s. 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947.

facts.text: Baij Nath Prasad Tripathi convicted of offences under s. 161 IPC and s. 5 Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: He was prosecuted in the Court of Shri B. K. Puranik, Special Judge, Bhopal, and companyvicted of offences under s. 161, Indian Penal Code, and s. 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947.

facts.text: Baij Nath Prasad Tripathi sentenced to nine months rigorous imprisonment on each count.

anchor.surface_text: He was sentenced to nine months rigorous imprisonment on each companynt.

facts.text: Baij Nath Prasad Tripathi appealed conviction and sentences to Judicial Commissioner of Bhopal.

anchor.surface_text: He preferred an appeal against the companyviction and sentences to the Judicial Commissioner of Bhopal.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner of Bhopal by judgment dated March 7, 1956 held no sanction for prosecution, Special Judge had no jurisdiction, set aside conviction and quashed proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Commissioner held by his judGment dated March 7, 1956, that numbersanction according to law had been given for the prosecution of the -petitioner and the Special JudGe had numberjurisdiction to take companynizance of the case the trial was accordingly ab initio invalid -and liable to be quashed.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner observed parties relegated to position as if no legal charge-sheet submitted.

anchor.surface_text: He then observed The parties would thus be relegated to the position as if numberlegal charge-sheet had been submitted against the appellant.

facts.text: On April 4, 1956, Chief Commissioner of Bhopal passed order under s. 72 of Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952 that Baij Nath Prasad Tripathi shall be tried by Shri S. N. Shrivastava, Special Judge, Bhopal for offences under Prevention of Corruption Act read with s. 161 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: On April 4, 1956, the Chief Commissioner of Bhopal passed an order under s. 7 2  of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952  No. XLVI of 1952  that the petitioner shall be tried by Shri S. N. Shri- vastava, Special Judge, Bhopal, for certain offences under the Prevention of Corruption Act read with S. 161, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Sudhakar Dube was petitioner in Petition No. 132 of 1956 and was a Sub-Inspector of Police in the then State of Bhopal.

anchor.surface_text: Sudhakar Dube, petitioner in Petition No. 132 of. 1956, was also a Sub-Inspector of Police in the then State of Bhopal.

facts.text: Sudhakar Dube prosecuted in Court of Shri B. K. Puranik, Special Judge, Bhopal on charge of accepting illegal gratification for showing official favour to Panna Lal.

anchor.surface_text: He was also prosecuted in the Court of Shri B. K. Puranik, Special Judge, Bhopal, on a charge of having accepted illegal gratification for- showing official favour to one Panna Lal.

facts.text: Special Judge by order dated January 10, 1956 held no legal sanction for prosecution, sanction by Inspector General invalid, quashed proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Special Judge by an order dated January 10, 1956, came to the companyclusion that numberlegal sanction for the prosecution of the petitioner had been given by the companypetent authority and the sanction given by the Inspector. General of Police was number valid in law he therefore held that the whole trial was null and void and he companyld number take companynizance of the offences in question.

facts.text: On February 7, 1956, Chief Secretary to Government of Bhopal accorded fresh sanction for prosecution of Sudhakar Dube for offences under s. 161 IPC and s. 5 Prevention of Corruption Act.

anchor.surface_text: On February 7, 1956, the Chief Secretary to the Government of Bhopal accorded fresh sanction for the prosecution of the petitioner for offences under s. 161, Indian Penal Code, and s. 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act.

facts.text: Sudhakar Dube moved Supreme Court for writs restraining respondents from prosecuting and trying him.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner then moved this Court for appropriate writs restraining the respondents from prosecuting and trying him for the offences stated in the fresh sanction aforesaid.

facts.text: Petitioners contend that by reason of cl. 2 of Art. 20 Constitution and s. 403 CrPC they cannot be tried for the offences.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of both the petitioners the companytention is that by reason of cl.  2  of Art. 20 of the Constitution and s. 403 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, the petitioners cannot number be tried for the offences in question.

facts.text: Earlier proceedings against petitioners held null and void ab initio due to lack of valid sanction.

anchor.surface_text: the earlier proceedings having been held to be null and void.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by K. Das J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS J.-

facts.text: Petitions seek writs restraining respondents from prosecuting and trying petitioners on criminal charges.

anchor.surface_text: These two petitions for the issue of appropriate writs restraining the respondents from prosecuting and trying the two petitioners on certain criminal charges in circumstances to be presently stated, raise the same question of law and have been heard together.

facts.text: Special Judges appointed under section 6 Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952 to try specified offences.

issues.text: Whether the petitioners can be prosecuted and tried again for the same offences by reason of cl. 2 of Art. 20 of the Constitution and s. 403 of the Code of Criminal Procedure

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of both the petitioners the contention is that by reason of cl.  2  of Art. 20 of the Constitution and s. 403 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, the petitioners cannot number be tried for the offences in question.

issues.text: Whether cl. 2 of Art. 20 of the Constitution applies to bar re-prosecution and punishment where earlier proceedings were null and void

anchor.surface_text: It is clear beyond any doubt that cl.  2  of Art. 20 of the Constitution has numberapplication in these two cases. The petitioners are number being prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once,, the earlier proceedings having been held to be null and void.

issues.text: Whether s. 403 of the Code of Criminal Procedure bars retrial where the earlier trial was not by a court of competent jurisdiction due to lack of sanction

anchor.surface_text: Section 403, Criminal Procedure Code, applies to cases where the acquittal order has been made by a Court of companypetent jurisdiction but it does number bar a retrial of the accused in cases where such an order has been made by a companyrt which had numberjurisdiction to take companynizance of the case.

issues.text: Whether there is a distinction between taking cognizance of an offence and jurisdiction to try such that absence of sanction affects only cognizance and not jurisdiction under s. 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the petitioners invited our attention to ss. 190, 191, 192, 529 and 530 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and submitted that in certain circumstances the Code drew a distinction between jurisdiction and taking companynizance.

arguments.claim: By reason of clause 2 of Article 20 of the Constitution and section 403 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, the petitioners cannot be tried for the offences in question

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of both the petitioners the contention is that by reason of cl.  2  of Art. 20 of the Constitution and s. 403 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, the petitioners cannot number be tried for the offences in question.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ull, we are of the view that the decisions referred to above state the legal position companyrectly. It is clear beyond any doubt that el.  2  of Art.

arguments.court_reasoning: Earlier proceedings null and void ab initio due to lack of sanction; no prosecution/punishment more than once under Art.20(2); s.403 requires competent jurisdiction which was absent

arguments.claim: Clause 2 of Article 20 has no application as petitioners are not being prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once; earlier proceedings held null and void

anchor.surface_text: It is clear beyond any doubt that cl.  2  of Art. 20 of the Constitution has numberapplication in these two cases. The petitioners are number being prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once,, the earlier proceedings having been held to be null and void.

arguments.claim: Section 403 CrPC applies only to trials by a court of competent jurisdiction; does not bar retrial where court lacked jurisdiction due to absence of sanction

anchor.surface_text: Section 403, Criminal Procedure Code, applies to cases where the acquittal order has been made by a Court of companypetent jurisdiction but it does number bar a retrial of the accused in cases where such an order has been made by a companyrt which had numberjurisdiction to take companynizance of the case.

arguments.claim: Section 403 CrPC is based on trial before a court competent to hear and determine the case; incompetent if no sanction obtained

anchor.surface_text: The Privy Council decision is directly in point, and it was there held that the whole basis of s. 403  1  was that the first trial should have been before a Court companypetent to hear and determine the case and to record a verdict of companyviction or acquittal if the Court was number so companypetent, as for example where the required sanction for the prosecution was number obtained

arguments.claim: In absence of valid sanction, trial was by court without jurisdiction to take cognizance

anchor.surface_text: It is quite apparent on this record that in the absence of a valid sanction the trial of the appellant in the first instance was by a magistrate who had numberjurisdiction to try him.

arguments.claim: The Code of Criminal Procedure draws a distinction between taking cognizance and jurisdiction in certain circumstances (ss.190,191,192,529,530 CrPC)

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the petitioners invited our attention to ss. 190, 191, 192, 529 and 530 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and submitted that in certain circumstances the Code drew a distinction between jurisdiction and I taking companynizance.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: risdiction. The distinction was drawn in a case where a Magistrate duly empowered to companymit cases to the Sessions Court companymitted ail accused

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinction irrelevant here; s.6 PCA mandatory bars cognizance without sanction, hence no jurisdiction to try; s.530 voids proceedings by unempowered magistrate; s.529(e) inapplicable

arguments.claim: Absence of sanction under s.6 Prevention of Corruption Act means no court can take cognizance or have jurisdiction to try

anchor.surface_text: Assuming, however, that in certain cases one Magistrate may take companynizance and another Magistrate may try an accused person, it is difficult to appreciate how any Court can try the petitioners of these cases in the absence of a sanction in view of the mandatory provisions of s. 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947.

arguments.claim: Section 530 CrPC provides that proceedings by magistrate not empowered to try are void, supporting lack of jurisdiction without sanction

anchor.surface_text: Section 530 of the Code is really against the companytention of learned companynsel, for it states, inter alia, that if any Magistrate number being empowered by law to try all offender, tries him, then the proceedings shall be void.

arguments.claim: Section 529(e) CrPC is merely an exception for taking cognizance under s.190(1)(a)(b); no bearing where sanction required but absent

anchor.surface_text: Section 529  e  is merely an exception in the matter of taking companynizance of an offence under s. 190, sub-s.  1 , cls.  a  and  b  it has numberbearing in a case where sanction is necessary and numbersanction in accordance with law has been obtained.

arguments.claim: Observations of Braund J. in Basdeo v. Emperor distinguishing taking cognizance and jurisdiction support that lack of sanction affects only cognizance

anchor.surface_text: As part of his arguments, learned companynsel for the petitioners referred to certain observations made by Braund J. in a decision of the Allahabad High Court, Basdeo v. Emperor  1 , where the learned Judge drew a distinction between taking companynizance and jurisdiction.

arguments.court_reasoning: Facts different (irregular committal under s.254 CrPC); no consideration of mandatory s.6 PCA; observations context-specific, not abstract propositions

arguments.claim: Precedents (Yusofalli Mulla PC, Basdeo Agarwalla FC, Budha Mal SC) conclude the point against petitioners

anchor.surface_text: Now, it is necessary to state that the point taken by learned companynsel for the petitioners is really companycluded by three decisions- a  one of the Privy Council, b  another of the Federal Court and  c  the third of this Court itself.

arguments.claim: Petitioners' counsel's attempt to distinguish precedents is unpersuasive; precedents state law correctly

anchor.surface_text: After the pronouncements made in the decisions referred to above, it is really unnecessary to embark on a further or fuller discussion of the point raised, except merely to state that we have heard learned companynsel for the petitioners who made a vain attempt with a crusading pertinacity worthy of a better cause, to show that the Privy Council decision was wrong and the decision of this Court required reconsideration

holdings.text: Section 403, Criminal Procedure Code, applies to cases where the acquittal order has been made by a Court of competent jurisdiction but it does not bar a retrial of the accused in cases where such an order has been made by a court which had no jurisdiction to take cognizance of the case.

anchor.surface_text: Section 403, Criminal Procedure Code, applies to cases where the acquittal order has been made by a Court of competent jurisdiction but it does not bar a retrial of the accused in cases where such an order has been made by a court which had no jurisdiction to take cognizance of the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.403 requires previous trial by competent court; lack of sanction deprives jurisdiction; follows Privy Council (Yusofalli), Federal Court (Basdeo Agarwalla), and Supreme Court (Budha Mal) precedents.

holdings.text: It is clear beyond any doubt that cl. 2 of Art. 20 of the Constitution has no application in these two cases. The petitioners are not being prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once, the earlier proceedings having been held to be null and void.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear beyond any doubt that cl. 2 of Art. 20 of the Constitution has no application in these two cases. The petitioners are not being prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once,, the earlier proceedings having been held to be null and void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.20(2) protects only against double prosecution and punishment; null and void proceedings ab initio due to lack of sanction do not constitute prior prosecution or punishment.

holdings.text: In the absence of a valid sanction the trial of the appellant in the first instance was by a magistrate who had no jurisdiction to try him.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite apparent on this record that in the absence of a valid sanction the trial of the appellant in the first instance was by a magistrate who had no jurisdiction to try him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6 Prevention of Corruption Act mandatory; no sanction means no jurisdiction to take cognizance or try, rendering proceedings void ab initio.

holdings.text: [I]t is difficult to appreciate how any Court can try the petitioners of these cases in the absence of a sanction in view of the mandatory provisions of s. 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947. If no Court can take cognizance of the offences in question without a legal sanction, it is obvious that no Court can be said to be a Court of competent jurisdiction to try those offences and that any trial in the absence of such sanction must be null and void.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming, however, that in certain cases one Magistrate may take cognizance and another Magistrate may try an accused person, it is difficult to appreciate how any Court can try the petitioners of these cases in the absence of a sanction in view of the mandatory provisions of s. 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between cognizance and jurisdiction irrelevant; s.6 PCA bars cognizance and thus jurisdiction without sanction; ss.190,529,530 CrPC do not override mandatory sanction requirement.

holdings.text: Section 530 of the Code is really against the contention of learned counsel, for it states, inter alia, that if any Magistrate not being empowered by law to try all offender, tries him, then the proceedings shall be void.

anchor.surface_text: Section 530 of the Code is really against the contention of learned counsel, for it states, inter alia, that if any Magistrate not being empowered by law to try all offender, tries him, then the proceedings shall be void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.530 CrPC voids proceedings by magistrate lacking empowerment to try, applicable where no sanction empowers trial under s.6 PCA.

holdings.text: Section 529(e) is merely an exception in the matter of taking cognizance of an offence under s. 190, sub-s. (1), cls. (a) and (b) it has no bearing in a case where sanction is necessary and no sanction in accordance with law has been obtained.

anchor.surface_text: Section 529 e is merely an exception in the matter of taking cognizance of an offence under s. 190, sub-s. 1 , cls. a and b it has no bearing in a case where sanction is necessary and no sanction in accordance with law has been obtained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.529(e) CrPC limited to irregularities in cognizance under s.190(1)(a)(b); inapplicable to mandatory sanction requirement under s.6 PCA.

holdings.text: [T]he decisions referred to above state the legal position correctly.

anchor.surface_text: After the pronouncements made in the decisions referred to above, it is really unnecessary to embark on a further or fuller discussion of the point raised, except merely to state that we have heard learned counsel for the petitioners who made a vain attempt with a crusading pertinacity worthy of a better cause, to show that the Privy Council decision was wrong and the decision of this Court required reconsideration, and having heard learned counsel in full, we are of the view that the decisions referred to above state the legal position correctly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms binding precedents (Yusofalli Mulla PC, Basdeo Agarwalla FC, Budha Mal SC) correctly state law on jurisdiction and s.403 despite petitioner's arguments to distinguish or reconsider.

precedents.cited_proposition: the whole basis of s. 403(1) was that the first trial should have been before a Court competent to hear and determine the case and to record a verdict of conviction or acquittal if the Court was not so competent, as for example where the required sanction for the prosecution was not obtained, it was irrelevant that it was competent to try other cases of the same class or the case against the particular accused in different circumstances

precedents.cited_holding: Section 403, Criminal Procedure Code, applies to cases where the acquittal order has been made by a Court of competent jurisdiction but it does not bar a retrial of the accused in cases where such an order has been made by a court which had no jurisdiction to take cognizance of the case

anchor.surface_text: Section 403, Criminal Procedure Code, applies to cases where the acquittal order has been made by a Court of competent jurisdiction but it does not bar a retrial of the accused in cases where such an order has been made by a court which had no jurisdiction to take cognizance of the case.

It is clear beyond any doubt that el. 2 of Art. 20 of the Constitution has numberapplication in these two cases. The petitioners are number being prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once,, the earlier proceedings having been held to be null and void. With regard to s. 403, Code of Criminal Procedure, it is enough to state that the petitioners were number tried,- in the earlier proceedings, by a Court of companypetent jurisdiction, number is there any companyviction or acquittal in force within the meaning of s. 403. 1  of the Code, to stand as a bar against their trial for the same offences.

It is clear beyond any doubt that cl. 2 of Art. 20 of the Constitution has no application in these two cases. The petitioners are not being prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once,, the earlier proceedings having been held to be null and void.
